sain

Standard Rust core types implementations for Python.

Equivalent types
  • Option<T> -> Option[T] | Some[T]
  • Result<T, E> -> Result[T, E]
  • Error -> Error
  • Vec<T> -> Vec[T]
  • Default<T> -> Default[T]
  • AsRef<T> -> AsRef[T]
  • AsMut<T> -> AsMut[T]
  • Iter<Item> -> Iter[Item]
  • OnceLock<T> -> Once[T]
Equivalent macros

As decorators.

  • cfg!() -> sain.cfg
  • todo!() -> sain.todo. This is not a decorator.
  • deprecated!() -> sain.deprecated
  • unimplemented!() -> sain.unimplemented
  • #[cfg_attr] -> sain.cfg_attr
  • #[doc(...)] -> sain.doc(...)

 35- `Option<T>` -> `Option[T]` | `Some[T]`
 36- `Result<T, E>` -> `Result[T, E]`
 37- `Error` -> `Error`

 39- `Default<T>` -> `Default[T]`
 40- `AsRef<T>` -> `AsRef[T]`
 41- `AsMut<T>` -> `AsMut[T]`
 42- `Iter<Item>` -> `Iter[Item]`
 43- `OnceLock<T>` -> `Once[T]`

def cfg( target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'unix', 'windows']] = None, requires: str | None = None, python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> bool: 
187def cfg(
188    target_os: System | None = None,
189    requires: str | None = None,
190    python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None,
191    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
192    impl: Python | None = None,
193) -> bool:
194    """A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns `True`.
195
196    .. warning::
197        The `require_modules` parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release.
198        Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.
199
200    The difference between this function and `cfg_attr` is that this function will not raise an exception.
201    Instead it will return `False` if any of the attributes fails.
202
203    Example
204    -------
205    ```py
206    import sain
207
208    if sain.cfg(target_os="windows"):
209        print("Windows")
210    elif sain.cfg(target_os="linux"):
211        print("Linux")
212    else:
213        print("Something else")
214    ```
215
216    Parameters
217    ----------
218    requires : `str | None`
219        A required module to run the object.
220    target_os : `str | None`
221        The targeted operating system thats required for the object to be ran.
222    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
223        The targeted Python version thats required for the object to be ran.
224
225        Format must be `(3, 9, 5)`.
226    target_arch : `str | None`
227        The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object to be ran.
228    impl : `str | None`
229        The Python implementation thats required for the object to be ran.
230
231    Returns
232    -------
233    `bool`
234        The condition that was checked.
235    """
236    checker = _AttrCheck(
237        lambda: None,
238        no_raise=True,
239        requires=requires,
240        target_os=target_os,
241        python_version=python_version,
242        target_arch=target_arch,
243        impl=impl,
244    )
245    return checker.internal_check()

A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns True.

The require_modules parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release. Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.

The difference between this function and cfg_attr is that this function will not raise an exception. Instead it will return False if any of the attributes fails.

Example
import sain

if sain.cfg(target_os="windows"):
    print("Windows")
elif sain.cfg(target_os="linux"):
    print("Linux")
else:
    print("Something else")
Parameters
  • requires (str | None): A required module to run the object.
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system thats required for the object to be ran.

  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version thats required for the object to be ran.

    Format must be (3, 9, 5).

  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object to be ran.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation thats required for the object to be ran.
Returns
  • bool: The condition that was checked.
def cfg_attr( *, requires: str | None = None, target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'unix', 'windows']] = None, python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> collections.abc.Callable[[~F], ~F]: 
102def cfg_attr(
103    *,
104    requires: str | None = None,
105    target_os: System | None = None,
106    python_version: tuple[int, int, int] | None = None,
107    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
108    impl: Python | None = None,
109) -> collections.Callable[[F], F]:
110    """Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.
111
112    If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns `False`,
113    `RuntimeError` will be raised and the object will not run.
114
115    .. warning::
116        The `require_modules` parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation
117        and will be removed in a future release.
118        Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.
119
120    Example
121    -------
122    ```py
123    import sain
124
125    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
126    def windows_only():
127        # Do stuff with Windows's API.
128        ...
129
130    # Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
131    # when creating the instance.
132    @sain.cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
133    class Zoo:
134        @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
135        def bark(self) -> None:
136            windows_only()  # RuntimeError("Windows OS only!)
137
138    # An instance will not be created if raised.
139    zoo = Zoo()
140    # RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
141    zoo.bark()
142    # Whats zoo??
143    ```
144
145    Parameters
146    ----------
147    requires : `str | None`
148        A required module to run the object.
149    target_os : `str | None`
150        The targeted operating system thats required for the object.
151    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
152        The targeted Python version thats required for the object.
153        Format must be `(3, 9, 5)`.
154    target_arch : `str | None`
155        The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object.
156    impl : `str | None`
157        The Python implementation thats required for the object.
158
159    Raises
160    ------
161    `RuntimeError`
162        This fails if any of the attributes returns `False`. `required_modules` is not included.
163    `ModuleNotFoundError`
164        If the module check fails. i.e., if `required_modules` was provided and it returns `False`.
165    `ValueError`
166        If the passed Python implementation is unknown.
167    """
168
169    def decorator(callback: F) -> F:
170        @functools.wraps(callback)
171        def wrapper(*args: typing.Any, **kwargs: typing.Any) -> F:
172            checker = _AttrCheck(
173                callback,
174                requires=requires,
175                target_os=target_os,
176                python_version=python_version,
177                target_arch=target_arch,
178                impl=impl,
179            )
180            return checker(*args, **kwargs)
181
182        return typing.cast(F, wrapper)
183
184    return decorator

Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.

If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns False, RuntimeError will be raised and the object will not run.

The require_modules parameter is bugged and scheduled for deprecation and will be removed in a future release. Instead, directly import modules at the top of the file or function.

Example
import sain

@sain.cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
def windows_only():
    # Do stuff with Windows's API.
    ...

# Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
# when creating the instance.
@sain.cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
class Zoo:
    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
    def bark(self) -> None:
        windows_only()  # RuntimeError("Windows OS only!)

# An instance will not be created if raised.
zoo = Zoo()
# RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
zoo.bark()
# Whats zoo??
Parameters
  • requires (str | None): A required module to run the object.
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system thats required for the object.
  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version thats required for the object. Format must be (3, 9, 5).
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture thats required for the object.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation thats required for the object.
Raises
  • RuntimeError: This fails if any of the attributes returns False. required_modules is not included.
  • ModuleNotFoundError: If the module check fails. i.e., if required_modules was provided and it returns False.
  • ValueError: If the passed Python implementation is unknown.

57class Default(typing.Protocol[_T_co]):
58    """An interface for an object that has a default value.
59
60    Example
61    -------
62    ```py
63    from sain import Default
64
65    class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):
66
67        @staticmethod
68        def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
69            return {}
70
71    cache = Cache.default()
72    print(cache)
73    assert isinstance(cache, Default)
74    # {}
75    ```
76    """
77
78    __slots__ = ()
79
80    @staticmethod
81    def default() -> _T_co:
82        """Return the default value of the object."""
83        raise NotImplementedError

An interface for an object that has a default value.

Example
from sain import Default

class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):

    @staticmethod
    def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
        return {}

cache = Cache.default()
print(cache)
assert isinstance(cache, Default)
# {}
Default(*args, **kwargs) 
1430def _no_init_or_replace_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
1431    cls = type(self)
1432
1433    if cls._is_protocol:
1434        raise TypeError('Protocols cannot be instantiated')
1435
1436    # Already using a custom `__init__`. No need to calculate correct
1437    # `__init__` to call. This can lead to RecursionError. See bpo-45121.
1438    if cls.__init__ is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1439        return
1440
1441    # Initially, `__init__` of a protocol subclass is set to `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1442    # The first instantiation of the subclass will call `_no_init_or_replace_init` which
1443    # searches for a proper new `__init__` in the MRO. The new `__init__`
1444    # replaces the subclass' old `__init__` (ie `_no_init_or_replace_init`). Subsequent
1445    # instantiation of the protocol subclass will thus use the new
1446    # `__init__` and no longer call `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1447    for base in cls.__mro__:
1448        init = base.__dict__.get('__init__', _no_init_or_replace_init)
1449        if init is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1450            cls.__init__ = init
1451            break
1452    else:
1453        # should not happen
1454        cls.__init__ = object.__init__
1455
1456    cls.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
@staticmethod
def default() -> +_T_co: 
80    @staticmethod
81    def default() -> _T_co:
82        """Return the default value of the object."""
83        raise NotImplementedError

Return the default value of the object.

@typing.final
@dataclasses.dataclass(frozen=True, unsafe_hash=True)
class AsRef(typing.Generic[+_T_co]): 
 60@typing.final
 61@dataclasses.dataclass(frozen=True, unsafe_hash=True)
 62class AsRef(typing.Generic[_T_co]):
 63    """Represents an immutable reference to an object.
 64
 65    Example
 66    -------
 67    ```py
 68    from dataclasses import dataclass
 69    from sain import ref
 70
 71    @dataclass
 72    class User:
 73        id: int
 74        name: str
 75
 76    same_user = User(0, "sukuna")
 77    # Both keys point to the same user object.
 78    cache = {
 79        0: ref.ref(same_user),
 80        1: ref.ref(same_user)
 81    }
 82
 83    cache[0].object.id = 1
 84    assert cache[1].object.id == 1  # True
 85
 86    # Copying the object no longer points to it.
 87    # Unless the object is a collection.
 88    copy = cache[0].copy()
 89    copy.id = 2
 90    assert copy.id != cache[0].object.id  # True
 91    ```
 92    """
 93
 94    __slots__ = ("object",)
 95
 96    object: _T_co
 97    """The object that is being referenced."""
 98
 99    def copy(self) -> _T_co:
100        """Copy the referenced object.
101
102        .. note::
103            If the referenced object is a collection or contains a collection,
104            Then this will copy its reference.
105        """
106        return copy.copy(self.object)

Represents an immutable reference to an object.

Example
from dataclasses import dataclass
from sain import ref

@dataclass
class User:
    id: int
    name: str

same_user = User(0, "sukuna")
# Both keys point to the same user object.
cache = {
    0: ref.ref(same_user),
    1: ref.ref(same_user)
}

cache[0].object.id = 1
assert cache[1].object.id == 1  # True

# Copying the object no longer points to it.
# Unless the object is a collection.
copy = cache[0].copy()
copy.id = 2
assert copy.id != cache[0].object.id  # True
AsRef(object: +_T_co)
object: +_T_co

The object that is being referenced.

102        .. note::
103            If the referenced object is a collection or contains a collection,
104            Then this will copy its reference.
105        """
106        return copy.copy(self.object)

@typing.final
class Some(typing.Generic[~ValueT], sain.Default[NoneType]): 
 56@typing.final
 57class Some(typing.Generic[ValueT], _default.Default[None]):
 58    """The `Option` type. An object that might be `T` or `None`.
 59
 60    It is a drop-in replacement for `typing.Optional[T]`, But has proper methods to handle the contained value.
 61
 62    Example
 63    -------
 64    ```py
 65    value = Some("Hello")
 66    print(value)
 67    # Some("Hello")
 68
 69    # This will unwrap the contained value as long as
 70    # it is not `None` otherwise this will raise an error.
 71    print(value.unwrap())
 72    # "Hello"
 73
 74    none_value = Some(None)
 75    while none_value.unwrap():
 76        # Never unreachable!
 77
 78    # Solving it with `unwrap_or` method to unwrap the value or return a default value.
 79    print(none_value.unwrap_or(10))
 80    # 10
 81    ```
 82    """
 83
 84    __slots__ = ("_value",)
 85
 86    def __init__(self, value: ValueT | None, /) -> None:
 87        self._value = value
 88
 89    @staticmethod
 90    def default() -> None:
 91        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None`."""
 92        return None
 93
 94    # *- Reading the value -*
 95
 96    @property
 97    def read(self) -> ValueT | None:
 98        """Read the contained value."""
 99        return self._value
100
101    def unwrap(self) -> ValueT:
102        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
103
104        Example
105        -------
106        ```py
107        value = Some(5)
108        print(value.unwrap())
109        # 5
110
111        value = Some(None)
112        print(value.unwrap())
113        # RuntimeError
114        ```
115
116        Raises
117        ------
118        `RuntimeError`
119            If the inner value is `None`.
120        """
121        if self._value is None:
122            raise RuntimeError(
123                f"Called `Option::unwrap()` on {type(self._value).__name__}."
124            ) from None
125
126        return self._value
127
128    def unwrap_or(self, default: ValueT, /) -> ValueT:
129        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or returning `default`.
130
131        Example
132        -------
133        ```py
134        value = Some(5)
135        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
136        # 5
137
138        # Type hint is required here.
139        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
140        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
141        # 10
142        ```
143        """
144        if self._value is None:
145            return default
146
147        return self._value
148
149    def unwrap_or_else(self, f: FnOnce[ValueT], /) -> ValueT:
150        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or calling `f` to get a default value.
151
152        Example
153        -------
154        ```py
155        value = Some(5)
156        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: 10))
157        # 5
158
159        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
160        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: True))
161        # True
162        ```
163        """
164        if self._value is None:
165            return f()
166
167        return self._value
168
169    def unwrap_unchecked(self) -> ValueT:
170        """Unwrap the inner value immediately returning it.
171
172        ## Warning
173        Unwrapping the value knowing its `None` is considered Undefined Behavior.
174
175        Example
176        -------
177        ```py
178        v: Option[float] = Some(1.2)
179        v.unwrap_unchecked() # 1.2
180
181        v: Option[float] = Some(None)
182        print(v.unwrap_unchecked()) # Undefined Behavior
183        ```
184        """
185        #! SAFETY: The caller guarantees that the value is not None.
186        return self._value  # type: ignore
187
188    def expect(self, message: str, /) -> ValueT:
189        """Returns the contained value if it is not `None` otherwise raises a `RuntimeError`.
190
191        Example
192        -------
193        ```py
194        value = Some("Hello")
195
196        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
197        # "Hello"
198
199        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
200        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
201        # RuntimeError("Value is None")
202        ```
203        """
204        if self._value is None:
205            raise RuntimeError(message)
206
207        return self._value

209    # *- Functional operations -*
210    def map(self, f: Fn[ValueT, T], /) -> Some[T]:
211        """Map the inner value to a new value. Returning `Some[None]` if `ValueT` is `None`.
212
213        Example
214        -------
215        ```py
216        value = Some(5.0)
217
218        print(value.map(lambda x: x * 2.0))
219        # Some(10.0)
220
221        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
222        print(value)
223        # Some(None)
224        ```
225        """
226        if self._value is None:
227            return Some(None)
228
229        return Some(f(self._value))

231    def map_or(self, default: T, f: Fn[ValueT, T], /) -> T:
232        """Map the inner value to a new value or return `default` if its `None`.
233
234        Example
235        -------
236        ```py
237        value = Some(5.0)
238
239        # Since the value is not `None` this will get mapped.
240        print(value.map_or(10.0, lambda x: x + 1.0))
241        # 6.0
242
243        # This is `None`, so the default value will be returned.
244        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
245        print(value.map_or("5", lambda x: str(x)))
246        # "5"
247        ```
248        """
249        if self._value is None:
250            return default
251
252        return f(self._value)
253
254    def map_or_else(self, default: FnOnce[T], f: Fn[ValueT, T], /) -> T:
255        """Map the inner value to a new value, Or return default which maps to `default()` if its `None`.
256
257        Example
258        -------
259        ```py
260        value = Some(5.0)
261
262        # Since the value is not `None` this will get mapped.
263        print(value.map_or_else(lambda: 10.0, lambda x: x + 1.0))
264        # 6.0
265
266        # This is `None`, so the default func will be returned.
267        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
268        print(value.map_or_else(lambda: "5", lambda x: str(x)))
269        # "5"
270        ```
271        """
272        if self._value is None:
273            return default()
274
275        return f(self._value)
276
277    def filter(self, predicate: Fn[ValueT, bool]) -> Some[ValueT]:
278        """Returns `Some[None]` if the contained value is `None`,
279
280        otherwise calls the predicate and returns `Some[ValueT]` if the predicate returns `True`.
281
282        Example
283        -------
284        ```py
285        value = Some([1, 2, 3])
286
287        print(value.filter(lambda x: len(x) >= 2))
288        # Some([1, 2, 3])
289
290        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
291        print(value.filter(lambda x: x > 3))
292        # None
293        ```
294        """
295        if (value := self._value) is not None:
296            if predicate(value):
297                return Some(value)
298
299        return Some(None)

336    def and_ok(self, optb: Some[T]) -> Some[T]:

355            return Some(None)

357        return optb

359    def and_then(self, f: Fn[ValueT, Some[T]]) -> Some[T]:

377            return Some(None)

383    def iter(self) -> iter.Iter[ValueT]:
384        """Returns an iterator over the contained value.

397        if self._value is None:
398            return iter.iter(())
399
400        return iter.once(self._value)

402    def as_ref(self) -> Some[_ref.AsRef[ValueT]]:
403        """Returns immutable `Some[AsRef[ValueT]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
404
405        Otherwise returns `Some[None]`.
406
407        Example
408        -------
409        ```py
410        value = Some(5).as_ref().unwrap()
411        value.object = 0 # FrozenError!
412
413        owned = value.object
414        print(owned) # 5
415
416        # Create a copy of object.
417        clone = value.copy()
418        clone = 0  # Thats fine.
419        print(clone == owned) # False, 0 != 5
420
421        # None object.
422        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
423        print(value.as_ref())
424        # Some(AsRef(None))
425        ```
426
427        Raises
428        ------
429        `dataclasses.FrozenInstanceError`
430            When attempting to modify the contained value. Use `sain.AsRef.copy()` method to create a copy.
431
432            Or just use `.as_mut()` if you're dealing with mutable objects.
433        """
434        if self._value is not None:
435            return Some(_ref.AsRef(self._value))
436
437        return Some(None)
438
439    def as_mut(self) -> Some[_ref.AsMut[ValueT]]:
440        """Returns mutable `Some[AsMut[ValueT]]` if the contained value is not `None`,
441
442        Otherwise returns `Some[None]`.
443
444        Example
445        -------
446        ```py
447        value = Some(5).as_ref_mut().unwrap()
448        value.object = 0
449        print(value.object) # 0
450
451        # None object.
452        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
453        print(value.as_ref_mut())
454        # Some(AsMut(None))
455        ```
456        """
457        if self._value is not None:
458            return Some(_ref.AsMut(self._value))
459
460        return Some(None)

481    def is_some_and(self, predicate: Fn[ValueT, bool]) -> bool:
482        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None` and
483        the predicate returns `True`, otherwise returns `False`.

486        -------

491

494        # False
495        ```
496        """
497        return self._value is not None and predicate(self._value)

499    def is_none(self) -> bool:

512        ```
513        """

522        return self.unwrap()

531        if not isinstance(other, Some):
532            return NotImplemented

534        return self._value == other.read  # pyright: ignore[reportUnknownVariableType, reportUnknownMemberType]

540        return hash(self._value)

The Option type. An object that might be T or None.

It is a drop-in replacement for typing.Optional[T], But has proper methods to handle the contained value.

Example
value = Some("Hello")
print(value)
# Some("Hello")

# This will unwrap the contained value as long as
# it is not `None` otherwise this will raise an error.
print(value.unwrap())
# "Hello"

none_value = Some(None)
while none_value.unwrap():
    # Never unreachable!

# Solving it with `unwrap_or` method to unwrap the value or return a default value.
print(none_value.unwrap_or(10))
# 10
Some(value: Optional[~ValueT], /)

87        self._value = value
@staticmethod
def default() -> None: 
89    @staticmethod
90    def default() -> None:
91        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None`."""
92        return None

Default value for Some. Returns None.

read: Optional[~ValueT]

98        """Read the contained value."""

Read the contained value.

def unwrap(self) -> ~ValueT: 
101    def unwrap(self) -> ValueT:
102        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
103
104        Example
105        -------
106        ```py
107        value = Some(5)
108        print(value.unwrap())
109        # 5
110
111        value = Some(None)
112        print(value.unwrap())
113        # RuntimeError
114        ```
115
116        Raises
117        ------
118        `RuntimeError`
119            If the inner value is `None`.
120        """
121        if self._value is None:
122            raise RuntimeError(
123                f"Called `Option::unwrap()` on {type(self._value).__name__}."
124            ) from None
125
126        return self._value

class Iter(collections.abc.Iterator[~Item], collections.abc.Iterable[~Item], sain.Default[ForwardRef('Iter[ty_ext.Never]')]): 
 62class Iter(
 63    collections.Iterator[Item],
 64    collections.Iterable[Item],
 65    _default.Default["Iter[ty_ext.Never]"],
 66):
 67    """Builds an in-memory iterator over some Python iterable.
 68
 69    Example
 70    -------
 71    ```py
 72    iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
 73    # Limit the results to 2.
 74    for item in iterator.take(2):
 75        print(item)
 76    # 1
 77    # 2
 78
 79    # Filter the results.
 80    for item in iterator.filter(lambda item: item > 1):
 81        print(item)
 82        print(iterator.count())
 83    # 2
 84    # 3
 85    # 3
 86
 87    # Indexing is supported.
 88    print(iterator[0])
 89    # 1
 90    ```
 91
 92    Parameters
 93    ----------
 94    items: `Iterable[Item]`
 95        The items to iterate over. This must be an iterable.
 96    """
 97
 98    __slots__ = ("_items",)
 99
100    def __init__(self, items: collections.Iterable[Item]) -> None:
101        self._items = builtins.iter(items)
102
103    @staticmethod
104    @typing.final
105    def default() -> Iter[ty_ext.Never]:
106        """Return the default iterator for this type. It returns an empty iterator.
107
108        Example
109        -------
110        ```py
111        it = Iter.default()
112        assert t.next().is_none()
113        ```
114        """
115        return empty()
116
117    @typing.overload
118    @typing.final
119    def collect(self) -> collections.Sequence[Item]:
120        ...
121
122    @typing.overload
123    @typing.final
124    def collect(self, *, cast: _B) -> collections.Sequence[_B]:
125        ...

127    @typing.final
128    def collect(
129        self, *, cast: _B | None = None
130    ) -> collections.Sequence[Item] | collections.Sequence[_B]:
131        """Collects all items in the iterator into an immutable sequence.
132
133        Example
134        -------
135        ```py
136        iterator = Iter(range(3))
137        iterator.collect()
138        # (0, 1, 2, 3)
139        iterator.collect(cast=str) # Map each element and collect it.
140        # ('0', '1', '2', '3')
141        ```
142
143        Parameters
144        ----------
145        cast: `T | None`
146            An optional type to cast the items into.
147            If not provided the items will be returned as it's original type.
148        """
149        if cast is not None:
150            return tuple(map(cast, self._items))
151
152        return tuple(self._items)
153
154    @typing.final
155    def to_vec(self) -> Vec[Item]:
156        """Convert this iterator into `Vec[T]`.
157
158        Example
159        -------
160        ```py
161        it = sain.iter.once(0)
162        vc = it.to_vec()
163
164        assert to_vec == [0]
165        ```
166        """
167        return Vec(self)

169    @typing.final
170    def copied(self) -> Iter[Item]:
171        """Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.
172
173        .. note::
174            If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use `by_ref` instead.
175
176        Example
177        -------
178        ```py
179        it = Iter([None, None, None])
180        copied = it.copied()
181        assert it.collect() == copied.collect()
182        ```
183        """
184        return self.__class__(copy.deepcopy(self._items))
185
186    @typing.final
187    def by_ref(self) -> Iter[Item]:
188        """Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.
189
190        Example
191        -------
192        ```py
193        it = Iter([None, None, None])
194        for ref in it.by_ref():
195            ...
196
197        # Original not consumed.
198        assert it.count() == 3
199        ```
200        """
201        return Iter(copy.copy(self._items))

203    def next(self) -> Option[Item]:
204        """Returns the next item in the iterator, `Some(None)` if all items yielded.
205
206        Example
207        -------
208        ```py
209        iterator = Iter[str](["1", "2"])
210        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")
211        assert iterator.next() == Some("2")
212        assert iterator.next().is_none()
213        ```
214        """
215        try:
216            item = self.__next__()
217        except StopIteration:
218            return Some(None)
219
220        return Some(item)

222    def map(
223        self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem]
224    ) -> Iter[OtherItem]:
225        """Maps each item in the iterator to its predicated value.
226
227        Example
228        -------
229        ```py
230        iterator = Iter(["1", "2", "3"])
231            .map(lambda value: int(value))
232
233        # <Iter([1, 2, 3])>
234        for item in iterator:
235            assert isinstance(item, int)
236        ```
237
238        Parameters
239        ----------
240        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], Item]`
241            The function to map each item in the iterator to its predicated value.
242        """
243        return Iter(predicate(item) for item in self._items)
244
245    def take(self, n: int) -> Iter[Item]:
246        """Take the first number of items until the number of items are yielded or
247        the end of the iterator is reached.
248
249        Example
250        -------
251        ```py
252        iterator = Iter(['c', 'x', 'y'])
253        for mode in iterator.take(2):
254            assert mode in ['c', 'x']
255        # <Iter(['c', 'x'])>
256        ```
257
258        Parameters
259        ----------
260        n: `int`
261            The number of items to take.
262        """
263        return Iter(itertools.islice(self._items, n))
264
265    def take_while(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Iter[Item]:
266        """Yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `True`.
267
268        Example
269        -------
270        ```py
271        iterator = Iter(['VIP', 'Regular', 'Guard'])
272        for membership in iterator.take_while(lambda m: m is 'VIP'):
273            print(membership)
274
275        # VIP
276        ```
277
278        Parameters
279        ----------
280        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
281            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.
282
283        Raises
284        ------
285        `StopIteration`
286            If no elements are left in the iterator.
287        """
288        return Iter(itertools.takewhile(predicate, self._items))
289
290    def drop_while(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Iter[Item]:
291        """Yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `False`.
292
293        Example
294        -------
295        ```py
296        iterator = Iter(['VIP', 'Regular', 'Guard'])
297        for membership in iterator.drop_while(lambda m: m is not 'VIP'):
298            print(membership)
299
300        # Regular
301        # Guard
302        ```
303
304        Parameters
305        ----------
306        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
307            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.
308
309        Raises
310        ------
311        `StopIteration`
312            If no elements are left in the iterator.
313        """
314        return Iter(itertools.dropwhile(predicate, self._items))
315
316    def filter(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Iter[Item]:
317        """Filters the iterator to only yield items that match the predicate.
318
319        Example
320        -------
321        ```py
322        places = Iter(['London', 'Paris', 'Los Angeles'])
323        for place in places.filter(lambda place: place.startswith('L')):
324            print(place)
325
326        # London
327        # Los Angeles
328        ```
329        """
330        items: collections.MutableSequence[Item] = []
331        for item in self._items:
332            if predicate(item):
333                items.append(item)
334
335        return Iter(items)
336
337    def skip(self, n: int) -> Iter[Item]:
338        """Skips the first number of items in the iterator.
339
340        Example
341        -------
342        ```py
343        iterator = Iter([MembershipType.STEAM, MembershipType.XBOX, MembershipType.STADIA])
344        for platform in iterator.skip(1):
345            print(platform)
346        # Skip the first item in the iterator.
347        # <Iter([MembershipType.XBOX, MembershipType.STADIA])>
348        ```
349        """
350        return Iter(itertools.islice(self._items, n, None))

352    def zip(self, other: Iter[OtherItem]) -> Iter[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]:
353        """Zips the iterator with another iterable.
354
355        Example
356        -------
357        ```py
358        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
359        other = Iter([4, 5, 6])
360        for item, other_item in iterator.zip(other):
361            assert item == other_item
362        <Iter([(1, 4), (2, 5), (3, 6)])>
363        ```
364
365        Parameters
366        ----------
367        other: `Iter[OtherItem]`
368            The iterable to zip with.
369
370        Returns
371        -------
372        `Iter[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]`
373            The zipped iterator.
374
375        Raises
376        ------
377        `StopIteration`
378            If no elements are left in the iterator.
379        """
380        return Iter(zip(self._items, other))

382    def all(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:

388        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])

405        return all(predicate(item) for item in self._items)

431    def sort(
432        self,

438

498    def reversed(self) -> Iter[Item]:
499        """Returns a new iterator that yields the items in the iterator in reverse order.

501        Example

520    def count(self) -> int:
521        """Return the count of elements in memory this iterator has.
522
523        Example
524        -------

526        it = Iter(range(3))
527        assert it.count() == 3
528        ```
529        """
530        count = 0
531        for _ in self:
532            count += 1

536    def union(self, other: Iter[Item]) -> Iter[Item]:
537        """Returns a new iterator that yields all items from both iterators.
538
539        Example
540        -------
541        ```py
542        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
543        other = Iter([4, 5, 6])
544        for item in iterator.union(other):
545            print(item)
546        # 1
547        # 2
548        # 3
549        # 4
550        # 5
551        # 6
552        ```
553
554        Parameters
555        ----------
556        other: `Iter[Item]`
557            The iterable to union with.
558
559        Raises
560        ------
561        `StopIteration`
562            If no elements are left in the iterator.
563        """
564        return Iter(itertools.chain(self._items, other))

566    def for_each(self, func: collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]) -> None:
567        """Calls `func` on each item in the iterator.
568
569        Example
570        -------
571        ```py
572        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
573        iterator.for_each(lambda item: print(item))
574        # 1
575        # 2
576        # 3
577        ```
578
579        Parameters
580        ----------
581        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]`
582            The function to call on each item in the iterator.
583        """
584        for item in self._items:
585            func(item)

587    async def async_for_each(
588        self,
589        func: collections.Callable[
590            [Item], collections.Coroutine[None, typing.Any, OtherItem]
591        ],
592    ) -> _result.Result[collections.Sequence[OtherItem], str]:
593        """Calls the async function on each item in the iterator concurrently.
594
595        Example
596        -------
597        ```py
598        async def fetch(username: str) -> dict[str, Any]:
599            async with aiohttp.request('GET', '...') as r:
600                return await r.json()
601
602        async def main():
603            users = sain.into_iter(["danny", "legalia"])
604            results = await users.async_for_each(lambda username: fetch(username))
605            for k, v in results.unwrap().items():
606                ...
607        ```
608
609        Parameters
610        ----------
611        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], collections.Coroutine[None, None, None]]`
612            The async function to call on each item in the iterator.
613        """
614        return await futures.spawn(*(func(item) for item in self._items))

616    def enumerate(self, *, start: int = 0) -> Iter[tuple[int, Item]]:
617        """Returns a new iterator that yields tuples of the index and item.
618
619        Example
620        -------
621        ```py
622        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
623        for index, item in iterator.enumerate():
624            print(index, item)
625        # 0, 1
626        # 1, 2
627        # 2, 3
628        ```
629
630        Raises
631        ------
632        `StopIteration`
633            If no elements are left in the iterator.
634        """
635        return Iter(enumerate(self._items, start=start))

637    def _ok(self) -> typing.NoReturn:
638        raise StopIteration("No more items in the iterator.") from None

640    def __getitem__(self, index: int) -> Option[Item]:
641        try:
642            return self.skip(index).first()
643        except IndexError:
644            self._ok()

648        raise NotImplementedError(
649            f"{type(self).__name__} doesn't support item assignment."
650        ) from None

652    def __contains__(self, item: Item) -> bool:
653        return item in self._items
654
655    def __reversed__(self) -> Iter[Item]:
656        return self.reversed()

658    def __repr__(self) -> str:
659        return f"<Iter: {type(self._items).__name__}>"

661    def __copy__(self) -> Iter[Item]:
662        return self.by_ref()

664    def __deepcopy__(self) -> Iter[Item]:
665        return self.copied()

668        return self.count()

671        return self

673    def __next__(self) -> Item:
674        try:
675            item = next(self._items)
676        except StopIteration:
677            self._ok()

def deprecated( *, since: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, removed_in: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, use_instead: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, hint: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None) -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
121def deprecated(
122    *,
123    since: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
124    removed_in: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
125    use_instead: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
126    hint: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
127) -> collections.Callable[
128    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
129    collections.Callable[P, U],
130]:
131    """A decorator that marks a function as deprecated.
132
133    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
134
135    Example
136    -------
137    ```py
138    from sain import deprecated
139
140    @deprecated(
141        since = "1.0.0",
142        removed_in ="3.0.0",
143        use_instead = "UserImpl()",
144        hint = "Hint for ux."
145    )
146    class User:
147        ...
148
149    user = User() # This will cause a warning at runtime.
150    ```
151
152    Parameters
153    ----------
154    since : `str`
155        The version that the function was deprecated.
156    removed_in : `str | None`
157        If provided, It will log when will the object will be removed in.
158    use_instead : `str | None`
159        If provided, This should be the alternative object name that should be used instead.
160    hint: `str`
161        An optional hint for the user.
162    """
163
164    def decorator(func: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
165        @functools.wraps(func)
166        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
167            obj_type = "class" if inspect.isclass(func) else "function"
168            msg = f"{obj_type} {func.__module__}.{func.__name__} is deprecated."
169
170            if since is not None:
171                msg += f" since {since}."
172
173            if use_instead is not None:
174                msg += f" Use {use_instead} instead."
175
176            if removed_in:
177                msg += f" Removed in {removed_in}."
178
179            if hint:
180                msg += f" Hint: {hint}"
181
182            _warn(msg)
183            return func(*args, **kwargs)
184
185        return wrapper
186
187    return decorator

A decorator that marks a function as deprecated.

An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.

Example
from sain import deprecated

@deprecated(
    since = "1.0.0",
    removed_in ="3.0.0",
    use_instead = "UserImpl()",
    hint = "Hint for ux."
)
class User:
    ...

user = User() # This will cause a warning at runtime.
Parameters
  • since (str): The version that the function was deprecated.
  • removed_in (str | None): If provided, It will log when will the object will be removed in.
  • use_instead (str | None): If provided, This should be the alternative object name that should be used instead.
  • hint (str): An optional hint for the user.
def unimplemented( *, message: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None, available_in: 'typing.LiteralString | None' = None) -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
211def unimplemented(
212    *,
213    message: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
214    available_in: typing.LiteralString | None = None,
215) -> collections.Callable[
216    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
217    collections.Callable[P, U],
218]:
219    """A decorator that marks an object as unimplemented.
220
221    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
222
223    Example
224    -------
225    ```py
226    from sain import unimplemented
227
228    @unimplemented("User object is not implemented yet.")
229    class User:
230        ...
231    ```
232
233    Parameters
234    ----------
235    message : `str | None`
236        An optional message to be displayed when the function is called. Otherwise default message will be used.
237    available_in : `str | None`
238        If provided, This will be shown as what release this object be implemented.
239    """
240
241    def decorator(obj: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
242        @functools.wraps(obj)
243        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
244            obj_type = "class" if inspect.isclass(obj) else "function"
245            msg = (
246                message
247                or f"{obj_type} {obj.__module__}.{obj.__name__} is not yet implemented."
248            )  # noqa: W503
249
250            if available_in:
251                msg += f" Available in {available_in}."
252
253            _warn(msg)
254            return obj(*args, **kwargs)
255
256        return wrapper
257
258    return decorator

def doc( path: 'Read') -> 'collections.Callable[[collections.Callable[P, U]], collections.Callable[P, U]]': 
261def doc(
262    path: Read,
263) -> collections.Callable[
264    [collections.Callable[P, U]],
265    collections.Callable[P, U],
266]:
267    """Set `path` to be the object's documentation.
268
269    Example
270    -------
271    ```py
272    from sain import doc
273    from pathlib import Path
274
275    @doc(Path("../README.md"))
276    class User:
277
278        @doc("bool.html")
279        def bool_docs() -> None:
280            ...
281    ```
282
283    path: `type[int] | type[str] | type[bytes] | type[PathLike[str]] | type[PathLike[bytes]]`
284        The path to read the content from.
285    """
286
287    def decorator(f: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
288        with open(path, "r") as file:
289            f.__doc__ = file.read()
290
291        @functools.wraps(f)
292        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
293            return f(*args, **kwargs)
294
295        return wrapper
296
297    return decorator

@typing.final
class Once(typing.Generic[~T]): 
 47@typing.final
 48class Once(typing.Generic[T]):
 49    """A synchronization primitive which can be written to only once.
 50
 51    Example
 52    -------
 53    ```py
 54    from sain.once import Once
 55    from uuid import uuid4, UUID
 56
 57    class Application:
 58        # Not initialized yet
 59        uuid: Once[UUID] = Once()
 60
 61        def send(self, id: UUID) -> None:
 62            ...
 63
 64    def spawn(app: Application) -> None:
 65        app.uuid.get().is_none() # True
 66        uid = app.uuid.get_or_init(uuid4())
 67        app.send(uid)
 68
 69    def run_application():
 70        # This will init the uuid if its not set or return it if it already is.
 71        app = Application()
 72        thread = threading.Thread(target=spawn, args=(app,))
 73        thread.start()
 74
 75        app.uuid.get().is_some()  # True
 76    ```
 77    """
 78
 79    __slots__ = ("_inner", "_lock", "_blocking")
 80
 81    def __init__(self, *, blocking: bool = True) -> None:
 82        self._blocking = blocking
 83        self._lock: _thread.LockType | None = None
 84        self._inner: T | None = None
 85
 86    @property
 87    def is_set(self) -> bool:
 88        return self._inner is not None
 89
 90    def get(self) -> Option[T]:
 91        """Gets the stored value.
 92
 93        `Option(None)` is returned if nothing is stored. This method will never block.
 94        """
 95        return _option.Some(self._inner)
 96
 97    def set(self, v: T) -> T:
 98        """Set the const value if its not set.
 99
100        This method may block if another thread is trying to access it.
101
102        Raises
103        ------
104        `RuntimeError`
105            If the value is already set. This will get raised.
106        """
107        if self._inner is not None:
108            raise ValueError("Value is already set.")
109
110        self._inner = origin = self.get_or_init(v)
111        self._lock = None
112        return origin
113
114    def clear(self) -> None:
115        self._lock = None
116        self._inner = None
117
118    def get_or_init(self, f: T) -> T:
119        """Get the value if its not `None`, Otherwise call `f()` setting the value and returning it."""
120
121        # If the value is not empty we return it immediately.
122        if self._inner is not None:
123            return self._inner
124
125        if self._lock is None:
126            self._lock = _thread.allocate_lock()
127
128        try:
129            self._lock.acquire(blocking=self._blocking)
130            self._inner = f
131            return self._inner
132        finally:
133            self._lock.release()
134
135    def __repr__(self) -> str:
136        return f"Once(value: {self._inner})"
137
138    def __str__(self) -> str:
139        return str(self._inner)
140
141    def __eq__(self, __value: object) -> bool:
142        if isinstance(__value, Once):
143            return self._inner == __value._inner  # pyright: ignore[reportUnknownVariableType, reportUnknownMemberType]
144
145        if isinstance(self._inner, type(__value)):
146            return __value == self._inner
147
148        return NotImplemented
149
150    def __ne__(self, __value: object) -> bool:
151        return not self.__eq__(__value)
152
153    def __bool__(self) -> bool:
154        return self.is_set

    app.send(uid)

def run_application():

    app = Application()
    thread = threading.Thread(target=spawn, args=(app,))
    thread.start()

    app.uuid.get().is_some()  # True

class Ok(typing.Generic[~T]): 
127@typing.final
128@dataclasses.dataclass(slots=True, frozen=True, repr=False)
129class Ok(typing.Generic[T]):
130    """Contains the success value of `Result[T, ...]`."""
131
132    _inner: T
133
134    ###############################
135    # * Boolean operations. * #
136    ###############################
137
138    def is_ok(self) -> typing.Literal[True]:
139        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `False` if it an `Err`.
140
141        Example
142        -------
143        ```py
144        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
145        assert value.is_ok() == True
146        ```
147        """
148        return True
149
150    def is_ok_and(self, f: F[T, bool]) -> bool:
151        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `f()` returns True..
152
153        Example
154        -------
155        ```py
156        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
157
158        assert value.is_ok_and(lambda inner: inner == "value")
159        # True
160        ```
161        """
162        return self.is_ok() and f(self._inner)
163
164    # These are never truthy in an `Ok` instance.
165    def is_err(self) -> typing.Literal[False]:
166        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Err`.
167
168        Example
169        -------
170        ```py
171        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
172
173        assert value.is_err() == False
174        ```
175        """
176        return False
177
178    def is_err_and(self, f: F[T, bool]) -> typing.Literal[False]:
179        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `Ok` and `f()` returns True..
180
181        Example
182        -------
183        ```py
184        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("value")
185
186        assert value.is_err_and(lambda inner: inner == "value")
187        # False
188        ```
189        """
190        return False
191
192    ###################
193    # * Extractors. * #
194    ###################
195
196    def expect(self, message: str, /) -> T:
197        """Return the underlying value if it was `Ok`, Raising `RuntimeError`
198        if it was `Err` with `message` passed to it.
199
200        Example
201        -------
202        ```py
203        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("owo")
204        ok.expect("err") # owo
205
206        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
207        err.expect("err") # RuntimeError("err")
208        ```
209        """
210        return self._inner
211
212    def unwrap(self) -> T:
213        """Return the underlying value if it was `Ok`, Raising `RuntimeError` if it was `Err`.
214
215        Example
216        -------
217        ```py
218        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("owo")
219        ok.unwrap() # owo
220
221        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
222        err.unwrap() # RuntimeError
223        ```
224        """
225        return self._inner
226
227    def unwrap_or(self, default: T, /) -> T:
228        """Return the underlying value if it was `Ok`, returning `default` if it was `Err`.
229
230        Example
231        -------
232        ```py
233        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("OwO")
234        ok.unwrap_or("uwu") # OwO
235
236        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
237        err.unwrap_or("uwu") # uwu
238        ```
239        """
240        return self._inner
241
242    def unwrap_or_else(self, f: F[E, T]) -> T:
243        """Return the contained `Ok` value or computes it from `f()` if it was `Err`.
244
245        Example
246        -------
247        ```py
248        ok: Result[int, str] = Ok(4)
249        ok.unwrap_or_else(lambda e: 0) # 4
250
251        err: Result[int, str] = Err("word")
252        err.unwrap_or_else(lambda e: len(e)) # 4
253        ```
254        """
255        return self._inner
256
257    def unwrap_err(self) -> typing.NoReturn:
258        """Return the contained `Err` value, Raising if it was `Ok`.
259
260        Example
261        -------
262        ```py
263        ok: Result[str, None] = Ok("buh")
264        ok.unwrap_err()  # RuntimeError
265
266        err: Result[str, None] = Err(None)
267        err.unwrap_err() == None
268        # True
269        ```
270        """
271        raise RuntimeError(f"Called `unwrap_err` on an `Ok` variant: {self._inner!r}")
272
273    ############################
274    # * Conversion adapters. * #
275    ############################
276
277    def ok(self) -> Option[T]:
278        """Convert `Ok[T]` to `Option[T]` if the contained value was `Ok` and `Option[None]` if it was `Err`.
279
280        Example
281        -------
282        ```py
283        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("buh")
284        value.ok().is_some() # True
285
286        value: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
287        value.ok().is_none() # True
288        ```
289        """
290        return _option.Some(self._inner)
291
292    def err(self) -> Option[None]:
293        """Convert `Err[T]` to `Option[T]` if the contained value was `Err` and `Option[None]` if it was `Ok`.
294
295        Example
296        -------
297        ```py
298        value: Result[str, None] = Ok("buh")
299        value.err().is_none() # True
300
301        value: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
302        value.err().is_some() # True
303        ```
304        """
305        return _option.NOTHING
306
307    def inspect(self, f: F[T, typing.Any]) -> None:
308        """Call a function to the contained value if it was `Ok` and do nothing if it was `Err`
309
310        Example
311        -------
312        ```py
313        def sink(value: str) -> None:
314            # do something with value
315            print("Called " + value)
316
317        x: Result[str, None] = Ok("ok")
318        x.inspect(sink) # "Called ok"
319
320        x: Result[str, str] = Err("err")
321        x.inspect(sink) # None
322        ```
323        """
324        f(self._inner)
325
326    def inspect_err(self, f: F[E, typing.Any]) -> None:
327        """Call a function to the contained value if it was `Err` and do nothing if it was `Ok`
328
329        Example
330        -------
331        ```py
332        def sink(value: str) -> None:
333            # do something with value
334            print("Called " + value)
335
336        x: Result[str, None] = Ok("ok")
337        x.inspect_err(sink) # None
338
339        x: Result[str, str] = Err("err")
340        x.inspect_err(sink) # Called err
341        ```
342        """
343
344    def map(self, f: F[T, U], /) -> Ok[U]:
345        """Map `Ok[T]` to `Ok[U]` by applying a function to `T`, Leaving `Err` untouched.
346
347        Example
348        -------
349        ```py
350        ok: Result[str, int] = Ok("1")
351        ok.map(lambda c: int(c) + 1) # Ok(2)
352
353        err: Result[str, int] = Err(0)
354        err.map(str.upper) # Err(0)
355        ```
356        """
357        return Ok(f(self._inner))
358
359    def map_or(self, f: F[T, U], default: U, /) -> U:
360        """Returns the provided default value if `Err`,
361
362        Otherwise extracts the `Ok` value and maps it to `f()`
363
364        Example
365        -------
366        ```py
367        x: Result[str, str] = Ok("foo")
368        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 3
369
370        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
371        assert x.map_or(lambda c: len(c), 42) == 42
372        ```
373        """
374        return f(self._inner)
375
376    def map_or_else(self, f: F[T, U], default: F[E, U], /) -> U:
377        """Returns the provided default value from a function if `Err`,
378
379        Otherwise extracts the `Ok` value and maps it to `f()`
380
381        Example
382        -------
383        ```py
384        x: Result[str, str] = Ok("four")
385        assert x.map_or_else(
386            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
387            lambda err: len(err)
388        ) == 8
389
390        x: Result[str, str] = Err("bar")
391        assert x.map_or_else(
392            lambda c: 2 * len(c),
393            lambda err: len(err)
394        ) == 3
395        ```
396        """
397        return f(self._inner)
398
399    def map_err(self, f: F[E, U], /) -> Self:
400        """Maps a `Result[T, E]` to `Result[T, U]`, leaving `OK[T]` untouched.
401
402        Example
403        -------
404        ```py
405        x: Result[str, int] = Ok("blue")
406        x.map_err(lambda err: err + 1) # Ok("blue")
407
408        x: Result[str, int] = Err(5)
409        x.map_err(float) # Err(5.0)
410        ```
411        """
412        return self

@typing.final
class Vec(typing.Generic[~T]): 
 70@typing.final
 71class Vec(typing.Generic[T]):
 72    """A contiguous growable alternative to builtin `list` with extra functionalities.
 73
 74    When initializing a vec, it will not build the underlying list until the first element gets pushed.
 75    Which saves a little bit of memory.
 76
 77    Example
 78    -------
 79    ```py
 80    names = Vec()
 81
 82    names.push('foo')
 83    names.push('bar')
 84
 85    print(names) # ['foo', 'bar']
 86    assert names.len() == 2
 87    ```
 88
 89    Equality is supported.
 90
 91    ```py
 92    vec = Vec((1,2,3))
 93    vec == [1, 2, 3] and vec # True
 94    ```
 95    """
 96
 97    __slots__ = ("_ptr", "_capacity")
 98
 99    @typing.overload
100    def __init__(self) -> None:
101        ...
102
103    @typing.overload
104    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T]) -> None:
105        ...
106
107    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T] | None = None) -> None:
108        """Initializes a new vec, This won't actually create the internal list until an element is appended into it.
109
110        Example
111        -------
112        ```py
113        names = Vec[str]()
114
115        names.push('foo')
116        names.push('bar')
117
118        assert names.len() == 2
119
120        # Initialize a vec from another iterable.
121        from_iter = Vec((1,2,3))
122        assert from_iter.len() == 3
123        ```
124        """
125
126        # We won't allocate to build the list here.
127        # Instead, On first push or fist indexed set
128        # we allocate if it was None.
129        self._ptr: list[T] | None = list(iterable) if iterable else None
130        self._capacity = 0
131
132    @classmethod
133    @macros.unstable(reason="not unimplemented yet.")
134    def with_capacity(cls, capacity: int) -> Vec[T]:
135        """Create a new `Vec` with at least the specified capacity.
136
137        This vec will be able to hold `capacity` elements without pushing further if `len(vec) == capacity`.
138
139        Example
140        -------
141        ```py
142        vec = Vec.with_capacity(3)
143        assert vec.len() == 0 and vec.capacity() >= 3
144
145        vec.push(1)
146        vec.push(2)
147        vec.push(3)
148        print(vec.len()) # 3
149
150        # This won't push.
151        vec.push(4)
152        ```
153        """
154        v = Vec[T]()
155        v._capacity = capacity
156        return v
157
158    def into_inner(self) -> collections.Collection[T]:
159        """Return an immutable collection over this vector elements.
160
161        Example
162        -------
163        ```py
164        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
165
166        assert vec.into_inner() == (1,2,3)
167        ```
168        """
169        return tuple(self)
170
171    def len(self) -> int:
172        """Return the number of elements in this vector.
173
174        Example
175        -------
176        ```py
177        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
178
179        assert vec.len() == 3
180        ```
181        """
182        return self.__len__()
183
184    @macros.unstable(reason="not unimplemented yet.")
185    def capacity(self) -> int:
186        """Return the capacity of this vector.
187
188        Example
189        -------
190        ```py
191        TODO
192        ```
193        """
194        return self._capacity
195
196    def iter(self) -> _iter.Iter[T]:
197        """Return an iterator over this vector elements.
198
199        Example
200        -------
201        ```py
202        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
203        iterator = vec.iter()
204
205        # Map each element to a str
206        for element in iterator.map(str):
207            print(element)
208        ```
209        """
210        return _iter.Iter(self)
211
212    def is_empty(self) -> bool:
213        """Returns true if the vector contains no elements."""
214        return self.len() == 0
215
216    def split_off(self, at: int) -> Vec[T]:
217        """Split the vector off at the specified position.
218
219        Example
220        -------
221        ```py
222        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
223        split = vec.split_off(1)
224
225        print(split, vec)  # [1], [2, 3]
226        ```
227        """
228
229        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
230        if at > self.len():
231            raise RuntimeError(
232                f"Index `at` ({at}) should be <= than len of vector ({self.len()}) "
233            ) from None
234
235        # No reason to split at 0.
236        if at == 0:
237            return self
238
239        split = self[at : self.len()]
240        self._ptr = self._ptr[0:at]
241        return split
242
243    def split_first(self) -> _option.Option[tuple[T, collections.Sequence[T]]]:
244        """Split the first and rest elements of the vector,
245        if the rest is empty, `Some[None]` is returned.
246
247        Example
248        -------
249        ```py
250        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
251        split = vec.split_first()
252        assert split == Some((1, (2, 3)))
253
254        vec = Vec((1))
255        split = vec.split_first()
256        assert split == Some(None)
257        ```
258        """
259        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
260        first, *rest = self._ptr
261        if not rest:
262            return _option.Some(None)
263
264        return _option.Some((first, tuple(rest)))
265
266    def first(self) -> _option.Option[T]:
267        """Get the first element in this vec, returning `Some[None]` if there's none.
268
269        Example
270        -------
271        ```py
272        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
273        first = vec.first()
274        assert ~first == 1
275        ```
276        """
277        return self.get(0)
278
279    def truncate(self, size: int) -> None:
280        """Shortens the vec, keeping the first `size` elements and dropping the rest.
281
282        Example
283        -------
284        ```py
285        vec = vec(1,2,3)
286        vec.truncate(1)
287        assert vec == [1]
288        ```
289        """
290        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
291
292        if self.len() == 0:
293            return
294
295        self._ptr = self._ptr[:size]
296
297    def retain(self, f: collections.Callable[[T], bool]):
298        """Remove elements from this vec while `f()` returns `True`.
299
300        In other words, filter this vector based on `f()`.
301
302        Example
303        -------
304        ```py
305        vec = vec(1, 2, 3)
306        vec.retain(lambda elem: elem > 1)
307
308        assert vec == [2, 3]
309        ```
310        """
311        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
312
313        if self.len() == 0:
314            return
315
316        self._ptr = [e for e in self._ptr if f(e)]
317
318    ##########################
319    # * Builtin Operations *
320    ##########################
321
322    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
323        """Push an element at the end of the vector.
324
325        Example
326        ```py
327        vec = Vec()
328        vec.push(1)
329
330        assert vec == [1]
331        ```
332        """
333        if self._ptr is None:
334            self._ptr = []
335
336        self._ptr.append(item)
337
338    # For people how are used to calling list.append
339    append = push
340    """An alias for `Vec.push` method."""
341
342    def get(self, index: int) -> _option.Option[T]:
343        """Get the item at the given index, or `Some[None]` if its out of bounds.
344
345        Example
346        -------
347        ```py
348        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
349        vec.get(0) == Some(1)
350        vec.get(3) == Some(None)
351        ```
352        """
353        try:
354            return _option.Some(self.__getitem__(index))
355        except IndexError:
356            return _option.Some(None)
357
358    def insert(self, index: int, value: T) -> None:
359        """Insert an element at the position `index`.
360
361        Example
362        --------
363        ```py
364        vec = Vec((2, 3))
365        vec.insert(0, 1)
366        assert vec == [1, 2, 3]
367        ```
368        """
369        self.__setitem__(index, value)
370
371    def pop(self, index: int = -1) -> _option.Option[T]:
372        """Removes the last element from a vector and returns it, or `sain.Some(None)` if it is empty.
373
374        Example
375        -------
376        ```py
377        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
378        assert vec.pop() == Some(3)
379        assert vec == [1, 2]
380        ```
381        """
382        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
383        return _option.Some(self._ptr.pop(index))
384
385    def remove(self, item: T) -> None:
386        """Remove `item` from this vector.
387
388        Example
389        -------
390        ```py
391        vec = Vector(('a', 'b', 'c'))
392        vec.remove('a')
393        assert vec == ['b', 'c']
394        ```
395        """
396        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
397        self._ptr.remove(item)
398
399    def swap_remove(self, item: T) -> T:
400        """Remove the first appearance of `item` from this vector and return it.
401
402        This will raise a `ValueError` if `item` is not in this vector.
403
404        Example
405        -------
406        ```py
407        vec = Vector(('a', 'b', 'c'))
408        vec.remove('a')
409        assert vec == ['b', 'c']
410        ```
411        """
412        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
413        try:
414            i = next(i for i in self._ptr if i == item)
415        except StopIteration:
416            raise ValueError(f"Item `{item}` not in list") from None
417
418        self.remove(i)
419        return i
420
421    def extend(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T]) -> None:
422        """Extend this vector from another iterable.
423
424        Example
425        -------
426        ```py
427        vec = Vec((1, 2, 3))
428        vec.extend((4, 5, 6))
429
430        assert vec == [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
431        ```
432        """
433        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
434        self._ptr.extend(iterable)
435
436    def copy(self) -> Vec[T]:
437        """Create a vector that copies all of its elements and place it into the new one.
438
439        Example
440        -------
441        ```py
442        original = Vec((1,2,3))
443        copy = original.copy()
444        copy.push(4)
445
446        print(original) # []
447        ```
448        """
449        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
450        return Vec(self._ptr[:])
451
452    def clear(self) -> None:
453        """Clear all elements of this vector.
454
455        Example
456        -------
457        ```py
458        vec = Vec((1,2,3))
459        vec.clear()
460        assert vec.len() == 0
461        ```
462        """
463        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
464        self._ptr.clear()
465
466    def __len__(self) -> int:
467        return len(self._ptr) if self._ptr else 0
468
469    def __setitem__(self, index: int, value: T):
470        if self._ptr is None:
471            self._ptr = []
472
473        self._ptr[index] = value
474
475    @typing.overload
476    def __getitem__(self, index: slice) -> Vec[T]:
477        ...
478
479    @typing.overload
480    def __getitem__(self, index: int) -> T:
481        ...
482
483    def __getitem__(self, index: int | slice) -> T | Vec[T]:
484        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
485        if isinstance(index, slice):
486            return self.__class__(self._ptr[index])
487
488        return self._ptr[index]
489
490    def __delitem__(self, index: int) -> None:
491        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
492        del self._ptr[index]
493
494    def __contains__(self, element: T) -> bool:
495        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
496        return element in self._ptr
497
498    def __iter__(self) -> collections.Iterator[T]:
499        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
500        return self._ptr.__iter__()
501
502    def __repr__(self) -> str:
503        return "[]" if not self._ptr else repr(self._ptr)
504
505    def __eq__(self, other: object) -> bool:
506        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
507        if isinstance(other, Vec):
508            return self._ptr == other._ptr
509        if isinstance(other, (collections.Iterable, collections.MutableSequence)):
510            return list(other) == self._ptr
511
512        return NotImplemented
513
514    def __ne__(self, other: object) -> bool:
515        return not self.__eq__(other)
516
517    def __le__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
518        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
519        return self._ptr <= list(other)
520
521    def __ge__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
522        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
523        return self._ptr >= list(other)
524
525    def __lt__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
526        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
527        return self._ptr < list(other)
528
529    def __gt__(self, other: collections.Iterable[T]) -> bool:
530        assert self._ptr is not None, "Can't access an empty sequence."
531        return self._ptr > list(other)
532
533    def __bool__(self) -> bool:
534        return bool(self._ptr)

A contiguous growable alternative to builtin list with extra functionalities.

When initializing a vec, it will not build the underlying list until the first element gets pushed. Which saves a little bit of memory.

Example
names = Vec()

names.push('foo')
names.push('bar')

print(names) # ['foo', 'bar']
assert names.len() == 2

Equality is supported.

vec = Vec((1,2,3))
vec == [1, 2, 3] and vec # True
Vec(iterable: collections.abc.Iterable[~T] | None = None) 
107    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[T] | None = None) -> None:
108        """Initializes a new vec, This won't actually create the internal list until an element is appended into it.
109
110        Example
111        -------
112        ```py
113        names = Vec[str]()
114
115        names.push('foo')
116        names.push('bar')
117
118        assert names.len() == 2
119
120        # Initialize a vec from another iterable.
121        from_iter = Vec((1,2,3))
122        assert from_iter.len() == 3
123        ```
124        """
125
126        # We won't allocate to build the list here.
127        # Instead, On first push or fist indexed set
128        # we allocate if it was None.
129        self._ptr: list[T] | None = list(iterable) if iterable else None
130        self._capacity = 0

Initializes a new vec, This won't actually create the internal list until an element is appended into it.

names.push('foo')
names.push('bar')

assert names.len() == 2

# Initialize a vec from another iterable.

assert from_iter.len() == 3
@classmethod
@macros.unstable(reason='not unimplemented yet.')
def with_capacity(cls, capacity: int) -> Vec[~T]: 
132    @classmethod
133    @macros.unstable(reason="not unimplemented yet.")
134    def with_capacity(cls, capacity: int) -> Vec[T]:
135        """Create a new `Vec` with at least the specified capacity.
136
137        This vec will be able to hold `capacity` elements without pushing further if `len(vec) == capacity`.
138
139        Example
140        -------
141        ```py
142        vec = Vec.with_capacity(3)
143        assert vec.len() == 0 and vec.capacity() >= 3
144
145        vec.push(1)
146        vec.push(2)
147        vec.push(3)
148        print(vec.len()) # 3
149
150        # This won't push.
151        vec.push(4)
152        ```
153        """
154        v = Vec[T]()
155        v._capacity = capacity
156        return v

Create a new Vec with at least the specified capacity.

This vec will be able to hold capacity elements without pushing further if len(vec) == capacity.

Example

assert vec.len() == 0 and vec.capacity() >= 3

vec.push(1)
vec.push(2)
vec.push(3)
print(vec.len()) # 3

# This won't push.
vec.push(4)

@typing.runtime_checkable
class Error(typing.Protocol): 
 55@typing.runtime_checkable
 56class Error(typing.Protocol):
 57    """`Error` is an interface usually used for values that returns `sain.Result[T, E]`
 58
 59    where `E` is an implementation of this interface.
 60
 61    Example
 62    -------
 63    ```py
 64    class PathError(Error):
 65        # The base message of this error. It will be shown when printing the error.
 66        def __init__(self, message: str = "...") -> None:
 67            super().__init__(message)
 68
 69        def source(self) -> _option.Option[type[Error]]:
 70            # If this error was derived from another error, It can be returned here.
 71            # For an example, This PathError might be derived from `IOError`
 72            # where `IOError` is also derived from `Error`.
 73            return Some(IOError)
 74
 75        def description(self) -> str:
 76            return "A very detailed description about the error."
 77
 78    def read(path: str) -> Result[str, Error]:
 79        try:
 80            with open(path, "r") as file:
 81                return Ok(file.read())
 82
 83        # FileNotFoundError is a subclass of IOError
 84        except (FileNotFoundError, IOError) as e:
 85            return Err(PathError(str(e)))
 86
 87    match read("/dev/null"):
 88        case Ok(content):
 89            ...
 90        case Err(err):
 91            print(err)
 92    ```
 93    """
 94
 95    __slots__ = ("message",)
 96
 97    def __init__(self, message: str = "") -> None:
 98        self.message = message
 99
100    def source(self) -> _option.Option[type[Error]]:
101        """The source of this error, if any."""
102        return _option.nothing_unchecked()
103
104    def description(self) -> str:
105        """Context for this error."""
106        return ""
107
108    def __repr__(self) -> str:
109        source = None if (src := self.source()).is_none() else src
110        return (
111            f'{type(self).__qualname__}(message: "{self.message}, source: {source!r})'
112        )
113
114    def __str__(self) -> str:
115        return self.message
116
117    # An error is always falsy.
118    def __bool__(self) -> typing.Literal[False]:
119        return False

Error is an interface usually used for values that returns sain.Result[T, E]

where E is an implementation of this interface.

Example
class PathError(Error):
    # The base message of this error. It will be shown when printing the error.
    def __init__(self, message: str = "...") -> None:
        super().__init__(message)

    def source(self) -> _option.Option[type[Error]]:
        # If this error was derived from another error, It can be returned here.
        # For an example, This PathError might be derived from `IOError`
        # where `IOError` is also derived from `Error`.
        return Some(IOError)

    def description(self) -> str:
        return "A very detailed description about the error."

        with open(path, "r") as file:
            return Ok(file.read())

    # FileNotFoundError is a subclass of IOError
    except (FileNotFoundError, IOError) as e:
        return Err(PathError(str(e)))

1430def _no_init_or_replace_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
1431    cls = type(self)
1432
1433    if cls._is_protocol:
1434        raise TypeError('Protocols cannot be instantiated')
1435
1436    # Already using a custom `__init__`. No need to calculate correct
1437    # `__init__` to call. This can lead to RecursionError. See bpo-45121.
1438    if cls.__init__ is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1439        return
1440
1441    # Initially, `__init__` of a protocol subclass is set to `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1442    # The first instantiation of the subclass will call `_no_init_or_replace_init` which
1443    # searches for a proper new `__init__` in the MRO. The new `__init__`
1444    # replaces the subclass' old `__init__` (ie `_no_init_or_replace_init`). Subsequent
1445    # instantiation of the protocol subclass will thus use the new
1446    # `__init__` and no longer call `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1447    for base in cls.__mro__:
1448        init = base.__dict__.get('__init__', _no_init_or_replace_init)
1449        if init is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1450            cls.__init__ = init
1451            break
1452    else:
1453        # should not happen
1454        cls.__init__ = object.__init__
1455
1456    cls.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
message

101        """The source of this error, if any."""
102        return _option.nothing_unchecked()

105        """Context for this error."""
106        return ""
